abstract.t: This document defines the JSON schema for using KAS ECC algorithms with the ACVP specification.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing KAS ECC algorithms using ACVP.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted in RFC 2119.

section.title: Capabilities Registration
section.t: ACVP requires crypto modules to register their capabilities. This allows the crypto module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of KAS ECC algorithms to the ACVP server.

The algorithm capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within the 'algorithms' value of the ACVP registration message. The 'algorithms' value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The 'algorithms' value is part of the 'capability_exchange' element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for details on the registration message.
Each KDF algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object.

section.title: Required Prerequisite Algorithms for KAS ECC Validations
section.t: Some algorithm implementations rely on other cryptographic primitives. For example, IKEv2 uses an underlying SHA algorithm. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

texttable.title: Required Prerequisite Algorithms JSON Values
texttable.c: CCM, CMAC, DRBG, ECDSA, HMAC, SHA
object with algorithm and valValue properties

section.title: KAS ECC Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values
section.t: Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values.

texttable.title: KAS ECC Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: Array of supported key agreement schemes each having their own capabilities

section.t: Note: Some optional values are required depending on the algorithm. Failure to provide these values will result in the ACVP server returning an error to the ACVP client during registration.

section.title: KAS ECC Component Test Capabilities JSON Values
section.t: Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values.

texttable.title: KAS ECC Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: Array of ECDSA curves values supported

section.title: KAS ECC Scheme Capabilities JSON Values
section.t: All other schemem capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values.

texttable.title: KAS ECC Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: Select the if Key Confirmation is supported
Select the key confirmation roles supported
Select the key confirmation type supported

section.title: KAS ECC Parameter Set JSON Values
section.t: Each parameter set advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values.

texttable.title: KAS ECC Capabilities JSON Values
texttable.c: AES key lengths in bits supported
CMAC MAC length in bytes, note: 8 lte MacLen lte Blocksize(16)

section.title: Test Vectors
section.t: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual KAS ECC function. This section describes the JSON schema for a test vector set used with KAS ECC algorithms.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client.The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

texttable.title: Vector Set JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of test group JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Groups JSON Schema
section.t: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the secure hash JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.
The test group for KAS ECC is as follows:

texttable.title: Vector Group JSON Object
texttable.c: The scheme for the test vectors. See for possible values
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in

section.title: Test Vectors JSON Schema
section.t: Each test group contains an array of one or more test vectors. Each test vector is a JSON object that represents a single test case to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each KAS ECC test vector.

texttable.title: Test Case JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the test case
The ECDSA static public key x coordinate
The ECDSA static public key y coordinate
The ECDSA ephemeral public key x coordinate
The ECDSA ephemeral public key y coordinate
nonceEphemCAVS ONLY USED BY C(1,2) and C(0,2) schemes with KC. nonce to be used in the MacData field
The 16 byte nonce concatenated to the "Standard Test Message"
The nonce supplied by the initiator to be used in the OI field in the PartyUInfo field.
The IUT ECDSA static private key
The IUT ECDSA static public key x coordinate
The IUT ECDSA static public key y coordinate
nonceEphemIUT ONLY USED BY C(1,2) and C(0,2) schemes with KC. nonce to be used in the MacData field
The IUT ECDSA ephemeral private key
The IUT ECDSA ephemeral public key x coordinate
The IUT ECDSA ephemeral public key y coordinate
The nonce supplied by the initiator to be used in the OI field in the PartyUInfo field.
Nonce used by the CCM function, if CCM is used to generate the Tag.
The tag (or MAC) GENERATED BY THE CAVS by using the DKM to MAC the Message with the specified method
The tag (or MAC) GENERATED BY THE IUT by using the DKM to MAC the Message with the specified method
P (Pass) or F (Fail) indicating if the IUT agrees with the Tag generated by the CAVS.

section.title: Test Vector Responses
section.t: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it must send the resonse vectors back to the ACVP server. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

texttable.title: Vector Set Response JSON Object
texttable.c: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of JSON objects that represent each test vector result,

section.t: Security considerations are addressed by the ACVP specification.
